bioghist.p: George W. Taylor (1901-1972) was a professor of industrial relations at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. He has been called "the father of American arbitration." Over his course of his career, he settled more than 2000 strikes, and served as labor advisor to five U.S. presidents and mentor to many labor economists in government and academia. In 1967, he helped draft the New York state civil service law which legalized collective bargaining in that state but which also banned strikes by public employeesâ€”legislation widely known today as the Taylor Law.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of George W. Taylor documenting his work in labor-management arbitration. Cases represented in this collection include the 1959 Steel Workers of America strike, the Operating Engineers (Philadelphia) case of 1950-1954, a 1963 rail workers dispute, and a 1962 airline pilot's dispute. Materials related to these cases include memos, correspondence, position statements, agreements, reports, transcriptions of testimony at hearings, and newspaper clippings. Several cases include reports to Congress and the President on the arbitration's progress and outcomes. The collection also documents the arbitration case between Kaiser Steel and the Steel Workers of America, with memos, correspondence, minutes, monthly reports, printed copies of agreements, newsletters, press releases. There are also records of Taylor's work on the President's Advisory Committee on Labor-Management Policy, and several of that group's subcommittees (including Monetary and Fiscal Policy, Technology and Automation, and Pensions). These materials include memos, minutes, reports of the Advisory Committee, bulletins and reports of the Labor Department and other government offices. Other materials in the collection include summaries and notes for jurisdictional disputes of the Congress of Industrial Organizations; minutes of the Advisory Board of the Office of War Mobilization and Reconversion (1944-1946); and printed bulletins and press releases from the Wage Stabilization Board (1951-1952).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
